Issues.Title: Use generic type on FormGroup class to support [formControl] directive in strict templates
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/releated to the feature request?

@angular/forms

### Description

Currently when targeting a `FormControl` embedded within a `FormGoup` via the `[formGroup]` directive, we have this issue on `<input />` elements 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12656294/157986211-a743cae4-2668-4fe2-bd7b-8bf86f7b3746.png)

### Proposed solution

This can be solved by using a type constraint generic type on the `FormGroup` class:

```typescript
export declare class FormGroup<T extends Record<string, AbstractControl> = {}> extends AbstractControl {
    controls: T;
    /**
     * Creates a new `FormGroup` instance.
```

### Alternatives considered

> Use the `formControlName` directive

I prefer programmatic solutions

> Separate the `FormControl` from the `FormGroup` and reference them directly

This is a solution but it's a but ugly and repetitive
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Use generic type on FormGroup class to support [formControl] directive in strict templates" (#45331)

Issues.Body: ### Description Tour of Heroes (TOH) Part 0 is missing button styles in `src/styles.css`. As a result, when developers go through the TOH, button CSS styles that are present in the live examples in src/styles.css are not present in the code snippets at the end of the lesson. This is most apparent in [TOH part-2](https://angular.io/tutorial/toh-pt2), where a list of buttons are shown without the expected styles. ### What is the affected URL? https://angular.io/tutorial/toh-pt0 ### Please provide the steps to reproduce the issue 1. Create new project in TOH Part 0 and apply code snippets to project 2. Follow steps in TOH part 1 and apply code snippets 3. Follow steps in TOH part 2 and apply code snippets 4. View output project styling for heroes.component.html without the expected button styling Minimal Reproduction https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-3vttek?file=src%2Fstyles.css ### Please provide the expected behavior vs the actual behavior you encountered **Expected**: heroes.component.html will have expected button styles applied as seen in the [live example ](https://stackblitz.com/run?file=src/app/heroes/heroes.component.html)for TOH part 2 **Actual**: heroes.component.html does not have button styles applied. ### Please provide a screenshot if possible Actual Expected ### Please provide the exception or error you saw ```true N/A ``` ### Is this a browser-specific issue? Issues.Title: feat(forms): Create a new ControlCollection interface.
Issues.Body: `FormGroup` and `FormArray` can both contain other controls as children. There are some places in our API, such as `AbstractControl.parent`, where we use the union type `FormGroup|FormArray`. Refactoring this into a named type will make it easier to add additional collection types, such as the upcoming `FormRecord`.

Issues.Title: Programmatic (view model) access to elements in content projection
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/releated to the feature request?

core

### Description

Can we have a way to programmatically access the content projected into `ng-content`, with and without selectors so we can conditionally append elements. 

Currently we must resorting to css tricks or native document queries to achieve this kind of behaviour

### Proposed solution

Obviously this is not valid Angular code but is indicative of what I am suggesting

As an example

```typescript
@Component({
  selector: 'app-my-component',
  template: `
    <ng-content select="h1"></ng-content>
    <ng-content select="h2"></ng-content>
    <ng-container #target></ng-container>
  `,
})
export class MyComponentComponent {
  @ProjectedContent({ select: 'input' })
  private projectedInputs: Array<ProjectedContentRef<HTMLInputElement>>

  @ContentChild('target')
  private targetContainer: ContainerRef

  ngAfterContentInit() {
    console.log(this.projectedInputs)
    this.targetContainer.insert(...this.projectedInputs)
  }
}
```

The idea here is that we grab the contents of `<ng-content select="input">` from within the view model, then after the conent has been initialized, it is inserted into a referenced `<ng-container>`



### Alternatives considered

css tricks and document queries in `ngOnChange` `ngAfterViewInit`
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Programmatic (view model) access to elements in content projection" (#45310)

Issues.Title: Reactive forms cleared input becomes empty string instead of null
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

forms

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

I have created a minimal reproducible sample of the problem here: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-4ltwow

Here you can see the mocked model input (that I receive from server API in the real app) is null at first, but after I edit the value in textbox and clear it, it becomes empty string.

I test this value server side to see if it has changed since before, and empty string is different from null so I have to test the difference from null AND empty string literally everywhere.

I have no alternative other than creating a directive and applying on every text input, but there are literally thousands and if I forget to put only one the problem arises again.

Shouldn't `getRawValue` return null if the input control is blanked? Wouldn't it be possibile to include an option in the form initialization (or a parameter of `getRawValue`) to get this desired behavior?

Thanks! 

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-4ltwow

Issues.Body: Previously, the migration only migrated constructor calls. Now, the migration will rewrite every usage, in all contexts. Both ways are technically correct, but migrating all symbols is likely to produce clearer and more readable results (although it will also produce a much larger diff).

Issues.Title: refactor(router): Make a few adjustments to createUrlTree for clarity
Issues.Body:
* `tree` function now accepts the old root rather than the old
  `UrlTree`. The `urlTree` argument was only used to get the `root`.
  This change makes it more clear what that pararmeter is used for and
  what's actually being used
* Move the `oldRoot` (previously `urlTree`) to be the first argument of `tree`.
  This change now mirrors the argument order for `replaceSegment` and
  can be read from left to right more easily "in this root,
  replace this old segment group with this new segment group".
* Extract `newRoot` to a variable. This just makes it more clear what's
  going on at the end rather than combining a bunch of operations into
  one.

These changes are being made so that hopefully a future refactor can be
done which does not rely on the `urlTree` argument at all in the
`createUrlTree` function. These refactorings will make it easier to see
1:1 functionlity in these various places.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "refactor(router): Make a few adjustments to createUrlTree for clarity" (#45306)

Issues.Title: docs: deprecated relativeLinkResolution in the Router
Issues.Body:
The `relativeLinkResolution` option was added as an option to opt-in to
corrected behavior when generating links relative to a route that has an
empty path parent. This was needed to avoid a breaking change. Since
then, we have switched the default to be the corrected behavior.
It's time to close the turn the lights off on this option so we no
longer have to maintain and document buggy behavior.

Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

compiler

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

Actually I'm not sure, if it's a bug, or a known drawback and I'm actually having false expectations. Just let me explain.

- We have an angular workspace that contains:
  - `foo-lib`: A library that is going to be used in `foo-app` (below)
    - Contains `AlphaModule`, which declares and exports `AlphaComponent`
    - Also contains `BetaModule`, which declares and exports `BetaComponent`
    - Both being exported via the lib's public-api.ts
  - `foo-app`: An Application that uses the router for lazy loading
    - theres an `AppModule`, an eagerly loaded startup module of the app
      - The `AppComponent`, declared and bootstrapped by the `AppModule`, only uses the `AlphaComponent` from the lib above
    - and theres a `LazyModule`, which is loaded lazily in the `AppRoutingModule` as described here: https://angular.io/guide/lazy-loading-ngmodules
      - The `LazyComponent`, declared and routed to via `LazyRoutingModule`, only uses the `BetaComponent` from the lib above

## Expectation:

Following the description above, when I build the app, I expect the final JS bundles...
- to have the `AlphaComponent` only referenced in the main.js bundle
- and to have the `BetaComponoent` only referenced in the lazy.js bundle

Because that's the point of doing lazy loading huh? Having stuff, that is not required in the main bundle, moved to their respective lazy loaded bundles, where it's actually needed

## Actual behaviour

In our production app, we once noticed a huge amount of unused JS inside our main bundle, reported by core web vitals measurements tool.

Further analysis identified an internal angular component library of ours as main problem and revealed that the expectation written above is actually false:

- As long as we use the lib *only* in our lazy module, everything is fine. The stuff we reference from the lib only appears in the lazy.js bundle
- But as soon as we use stuff from the lib also in our AppModule or components that directly or indirectly belong to it, everything else from the lib which is only used in lazy modules, also goes to the main.js bundle when compiling
- Referencing the example drawn above that means
  - The main.js bundle actually contains both `AlphaComponent` and `BetaComponent` from the lib, although `BetaComponent` is not used in any way in the `AppModule`, but only in the `LazyModule`
  - When we remove all `AlphaComponent` and `AlphaModule` references from our `AppModule` and components that belong eagerly to it, we find out that the `BetaComponent` now is actually contained in the lazy bundle, and not in the main bundle any more, that part follows my expectation.

## Workaround

However, the things written above are only true as long as the library only has one single entry point. This is the case for our internal component library. Each individual component is wrapped inside its own NgModule and most of them have no cross references between each other, it's mainly a collection of reusable ui-components. So we can always import only those NgModules we actually need, always thought we'd rely on tree shaking to reduce the bundle to what's actually being used (which is true unless you use lazy loading and reference the lib from different routes)

As soon as we create seperate secondary entry points for each entity in the lib which is meant to be used independently, the problem does not occur any longer.

I also tried that with non-angular libs (normal npm package with some typescript stuff being exported) - same issue.

## What is this?

Is it a bug?

Is it a problem, may it be known or unknown, which exists but is currently not resolvable (unless using sepearte entry points in the lib)? If that's the case, I think it should be mentioned in the docs about lazy loading, otherwise I don't think most devs are aware of this problem and just run into the same trap as we did. Blindly and unconciously.

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://github.com/paulheising/demo-lazy-loading-with-libs

Issues.Title: feat(@angular/cli): add `--global` option to `ng analytics` command
Issues.Body:
With this change we add a `--global` option to `ng analytics` command.

BREAKING CHANGE:

Several changes to the `ng analytics` command syntax.

- `ng analytics project <setting>` has been replaced with `ng analytics <setting>`
- `ng analytics <setting>` has been replaced with `ng analytics <setting> --global`
---

feat(@angular/cli): add `ng analytics info` command

With this change we add a subcommand to `ng analytics`. This command can be used tp display analytics gathering and reporting configuration.

Example:
```
$ ng analytics info                              
Global setting: off
Local setting: ci
Effective setting: ci
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(@angular/cli): add `--global` option to `ng analytics` command" (#22815)

This addresses the issue  when trying to disable analytics the prompt will be shown

```
ng analytics off
Would you like to share anonymous usage data about this project with the Angular Team at Google under Google’s Privacy Policy at https://policies.google.com/privacy? For more details and how to change this setting, see http://angular.io/analytics. (y/N)
```

Closes #16784

Issues.Title: feat(material/icon): SEO friendly ligature icons
Issues.Body:
The new way to use ligature icons, via a dedicated attribute, allow to hide
the font name from search engine results. Otherwise the font name, which was
never intended to be read by any end-users, would appear in the middle of legit
sentences in search results, thus making the search result very confusingto read.

New recommended usage is:

```diff
- <mat-icon>my-icon-name</mat-icon>
+ <mat-icon icon="my-icon-name"></mat-icon>
```

Fixes #23195
Fixes #23183
Fixes https://github.com/google/material-design-icons/issues/498
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(material/icon): SEO friendly ligature icons" (#24578)

Issues.Title: build: speed up docs deployment by not running a11y audit tests
Issues.Body:
We can speed up the docs deployment & monitor jobs by not running the
rather slower a11y audit tests. These should just be run in the docs
repo. The standard audit lighthouse tests should be a sufficient
indicator of whether the page is up-and-running properly.

Ideally in the future we would have proper e2e tests for the docs
site, but even those will never guarantee a 100%-working page.

Issues.Title: bug(cdkTextareaAutosize): Resizing only works properly if material styles are included
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

**Reproduction steps** 

Note: all Reproduction steps can be found in this [repository ](https://github.com/maro1993/resize-example-cdk)

1. Initialize project, install angular cdk 13.2.6, angular 13.2.6
2. create a textarea, bind the cdkTextareaAutosize to it (optionally bind max and min rows)
3. Fill Textarea with some characters 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/62110622/157763629-73cf0edf-63f6-4650-9f6f-4b3befb9b1e7.png)
4. Delete some lines to force a resize of the textarea ( by selecting multiple lines with the cursor or keyboard arrows )
5. Textarea is not resized
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/62110622/157763759-01818364-6ff1-4431-b105-ec8b1904b59c.png)

**Having a look at the problem** 

After some work i managed to narrow this down a bit. Apparently the resizing is working when a material-theme like indigo-pink.css is present and included in angular.json.

`                        "styles": [
                            "./node_modules/@angular/material/prebuilt-themes/indigo-pink.css",
                            "src/styles.scss"
                        ]`

At first that didnt make a lot of sense to me so i started debugging a bit aswell. Apparently with this stylesheet present the method **measureScrollHeight** in [autosize.ts](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/master/src/cdk/text-field/autosize.ts) is yielding a different result as when this stylesheet is not present. After checking the method i saw that there are some classes beeing added. So my suspection is that maybe one of those is missing without the stylesheet beeing present. After that i didnt proceed to check more and hope that this gives a direction how one can proceed solving this.

A minimal **working** repo with styles in angular.json can also be found here ( https://github.com/maro1993/resize-example )

### Reproduction

reproduction repo of the **bug** ->  https://github.com/maro1993/resize-example-cdk

a working example with an material theme beeing included and material package beeing added in package.json https://github.com/maro1993/resize-example


### Expected Behavior

expect textarea to resize ( more details in the description)

### Actual Behavior

textarea did not resize ( more details in the description)

### Environment


- Browser(s): Chrome Version 99.0.4844.51 (Offizieller Build) (64-Bit), Firefox 91.5.1esr (64-Bit
- Operating System Windows 10

"dependencies": {
    "@angular/animations": "~13.2.0",
    "@angular/cdk": "^13.2.6",
    "@angular/common": "~13.2.0",
    "@angular/compiler": "~13.2.0",
    "@angular/core": "~13.2.0",
    "@angular/forms": "~13.2.0",
    "@angular/material": "^13.2.6",
    "@angular/platform-browser": "~13.2.0",
    "@angular/platform-browser-dynamic": "~13.2.0",
    "@angular/router": "~13.2.0",
    "rxjs": "~7.5.0",
    "tslib": "^2.3.0",
    "zone.js": "~0.11.4"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "@angular-devkit/build-angular": "~13.2.6",
    "@angular/cli": "~13.2.6",
    "@angular/compiler-cli": "~13.2.0",
    "@types/jasmine": "~3.10.0",
    "@types/node": "^12.11.1",
    "jasmine-core": "~4.0.0",
    "karma": "~6.3.0",
    "karma-chrome-launcher": "~3.1.0",
    "karma-coverage": "~2.1.0",
    "karma-jasmine": "~4.0.0",
    "karma-jasmine-html-reporter": "~1.7.0",
    "typescript": "~4.5.2"
  }

Issues.Title: bug(mat-radio-group): Programmatically updating a form property with the same object value unchecks its mat-radio-button option
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

When programmatically updating a form property that happens to be an object with the same previous value, the `mat-radio-button` gets unchecked. When the form property is a string or a number, there's no problem.

### Reproduction

Link: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-lxats5?file=src%2Fapp%2Fapp.component.ts

Steps to reproduce:

1. After the application is done loading, you can see the different options being programmatically selected after a couple seconds, except when data `{ id: 3 }` is set more than once;
2. Once this happens, the third option is unchecked, even though the form property still has the correct value;


### Expected Behavior

Expected the mat-radio-button option to be selected correctly, even when the form property is updated with the same value more than once. There should be no difference if the value is a string or an object, since the `[checked]=condition` is supposed to take care of the checking rule.

### Actual Behavior

The mat-radio-button option is unchecked when its form property is updated with the same value more than once.

### Environment

- Angular: 13.2.5
- CDK/Material: 13.2.5
- Browser(s): Chrome, Firefox
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(mat-radio-group): Programmatically updating a form property with the same object value unchecks its mat-radio-button option" (#24559)

Issues.Title: feat(cdk-experimental/menu): Use DI instead of CdkMenuPanel to connect menus
Issues.Body:
This PR aims to simplify the API by eliminating `MenuPanel`, which was a directive that existed purely to glue together other components and directives. Specifically it was used to pass along the `MenuStack` and to associate a `Menu` with the trigger that opened it.

In the reworked API, `MenuStack` becomes injectable and we create a new base class for all menu triggers, `MenuTrigger` that is also injectable. The new injectables work as follows:
- All `MenuTrigger` provide both `MenuStack` and `MenuTrigger` to any `Menu` they open
- All `Menu` injects an optional `MenuStack` and `MenuTrigger`
- All `Menu` registers with its injected `MenuStack` and `MenuTrigger` at `ngOnInit`
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(cdk-experimental/menu): Use DI instead of CdkMenuPanel to connect menus" (#24558)

Issues.Title: docs-bug(COMPONENT): TITLE
Issues.Body:
### Documentation Feedback

There seems to be a lot missing in terms of CDK documentation. Specifically after supposed fixes have been created.

https://github.com/angular/components/issues/13588
https://github.com/angular/components/pull/18082#pullrequestreview-342953142

Quick searches reveal that any combination of CDK components leave engineers lost.
CdkDragDrop and scroll-UX is completely missing in the docs as well as examples of these CDKs combined. 
Certainly no mention of virtual scrolling on top of them.

I believe I've created issue tickets in the past regarding other Angular Material components. Hopefully we can get better docs and examples going.

Thanks for reading.

Issues.Title: fix(material-experimental/mdc-chips): Mirror aria-describedby to matChipInput
Issues.Body:
Updates mat-chip-grid to associate any ids set for aria-describedby to the matChipInput instance within the grid, if one exists.  See #24542 for information on why this is necessary.

Currently this PR creates a `setAriaDescribedBy` method on `matChipInput` and calls it from `mat-chip-grid` whenever `mat-chip-grid`'s `setAriaDescribedBy` method is called.  The internal logic mirrors that of `mat-chip-grid`.  This may not be the best way to go about this change; let me know if there's a better way to do it!

Fixes #24542
